docs.lead_paragraph: LIKE families trading their current home for a larger or smaller one as their space needs change, companies have been rearranging their corporate houses at an increased rate in the last six months due to mergers, acquisitions or consolidations, brokers say. That has led to more than doubling the amount of sublet space filtering back onto the 11-county northern and central New Jersey office market, which now stands at 4.3 million square feet, according to Grubb & Ellis, a national commercial brokerage. Subleases represent 17.4 percent of the overall available office space in the state today, according to Cushman & Wakefield, another national brokerage.

headline.main: In the Region /New Jersey; Office Space for Sublet Jumps as Companies Revamp

docs.abstract: Corporate relocations in New Jersey in recent months have more than doubled amount of sublet space filtering back onto office market in northern and central New Jersey; photos of two such buildings (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE inflation debate has been whittled down to a single issue. No longer does anyone fret much about shortages in the great array of goods and services that Americans consume. Sure, there can be temporary scarcities and bottlenecks, and short-lived price spikes. But in the eyes of the Federal Reserve, only one kind of shortage has the potential to be inflationary in the late 1990's: a labor shortage. And that, too, may be losing its teeth.

headline.main: Which Way the Fed? Sorting Out the Signals on Interest Rates

docs.lead_paragraph: MIDWAY through announcing his proposal to revamp Medicare last week, President Clinton seemed to notice that there were ghosts in the room. He recalled the first time he came face to face with the suffering of older Americans forced to choose between medicine and food -- during the rough, recessionary days of the 1992 Presidential campaign, when the plight of the uninsured and the under-insured burst into the public's consciousness.

headline.main: The Nation: Second Opinions; The Hard Lessons Of Health Reform

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton's last attempt to come to grips with nation's contradictory desires on health care discussed in light of hard lessons learned in earlier reform fiasco; photos; that struggle was, in retrospect, one of defining political conflicts of 1990's, and most of its tensions resurface as Clinton unveils plan to fortify Medicare's finances, add prescription drugs to benefits and spur more competition for Medicare customers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two executives of the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation were found guilty yesterday of defrauding Federal health care programs through the submission of bogus expense claims to the Government in the first jury verdicts stemming from the investigation of potential wrongdoing at the company. The two executives, Jay Jarrell and Robert Whiteside, were each found guilty by a Federal jury in Tampa, Fla., of six counts of fraud. They face up to five years in prison and $250,000 in fines on each count.

headline.main: 2 Found Guilty Of Hospital Fraud Charges

docs.abstract: Federal jury in Tampa, Fla, finds Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp executives Jay Jarrell and Robert Whiteside guilty of defrauding Federal health care programs through submissions of bogus expense claims to Government in first jury verdicts stemming from investigation of potential wrongdoing at company; third executive, Michael Neeb, is acquitted, while jury is unable to reach verdict for fourth defendant, Carl Lynn Dick; four executives were charged with conspiring for more than decade to overstate expenses at Fawcett Memorial Hospital in Port Charlotte, Fla; indictment states hospital defrauded Medicare and other Federal programs of more than $1.7 million (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: More than 1,200 nurses, health aides and hospital workers gathered outside Gov. George E. Pataki's midtown office yesterday to protest his proposals to cut Medicaid spending by hundreds of millions of dollars. Several said the cuts were forcing some financially squeezed hospitals to eliminate some employee benefits. ''We believe the Governor is not willing to compromise, and it's affecting the livelihood of health care workers and our patients,'' said Dennis Rivera, president of Local 1199, the National Health and Human Service Employees Union, which represents 150,000 health care workers in New York City.

headline.main: Health Workers Protest Planned Medicaid Cuts

docs.lead_paragraph: With the projected Federal budget surplus having grown substantially since they first set their budget plans earlier this year, Republican leaders in Congress said today that they would rethink their tax and spending proposals but would not necessarily channel the entire windfall into a bigger tax cut. The party's leadership in both the House and the Senate said the new surplus projections made them more determined to pass a tax cut of historic proportions despite the opposition of President Clinton.

headline.main: As Estimates of Surplus Grow, G.O.P. Rethinks Ways to Use It

docs.lead_paragraph: If there is one thing political observers should have learned in the 90's, it's to never underestimate the talent Republicans have for squandering a big advantage. George Herbert Walker Bush was invincible after the triumph of the Persian Gulf war. And yet there was Bill Clinton, only recently escaped from the Gennifer Flowers scandal, being sworn in as President on Jan. 20, 1993.
docs.abstract: Bob Herbert Op-Ed column, holding Republican Party is already right wing, hopes extremists follow through on threat to mount third-party challenge because Gov George W Bush is not conservative enough for them; cites Republican efforts in Senate to block debate on Democratic proposals aimed at curbing abuses by health insurers and health maintenance organizations (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The snazzy new drug benefit drew most of the attention. The rest of President Clinton's Medicare plan drew sparse comment, though many noted what they took to be its modest scope. Senator John B. Breaux, the Louisiana Democrat who as chairman of a recent Presidential commission proposed an overhaul of Medicare, compared the Clinton plan to ''the second cousin to real competition.''

headline.main: Economic Scene; 2 Medicare Plans, but Not So Far Apart

docs.abstract: Michael M Weinstein Economic Scene column on Pres Clinton's Medicare reform plan holds it seems as radical and pro-competition as plan proposed by Sen John B Breaux; holds Clinton's proposed drug benefit, while smart politics, offers inadequate coverage (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: They look like any of the anxious patients who walk into the city's polyglot emergency rooms. But there are telltale signs. Sometimes they arrive with luggage and with tourist visas in their pockets. Often they have crumpled notes from doctors back home in China or Africa.

headline.main: Ailing Foreigners Burden Emergency Rooms in U.S.

docs.abstract: Medical immigrants, mostly poor or middle-class foreigners from poor countries, are traveling to United States to seek care at emergency rooms in New York City and other big cities, where law says they must be treated if problems require immediate care; many hospitals, fearing anti-immigrant sentiment that has restricted access to health care in some states, resist counting such patients; medical immigrants are tiny but striking example of larger and growing problem of uninsured or underinsured patients, both citizens and immigrants, who rely on emergency rooms of financially-pressed hospitals; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Healtheon Corporation and WebMD Inc., the companies that are combining in an attempt to dominate the use of the Internet by the health care industry, are buying Greenberg News Networks, a privately held medical news service, for $250 million in stock, people familiar with the deal said yesterday. Healtheon, based in Santa Clara, Calif., agreed in May to buy WebMD, of Atlanta, for stock then valued at $3.9 billion. Healtheon has focused mainly on using the Internet to automate medical transactions, like insurance claims. WebMD operates a site that offers information to doctors and to patients, with revenues both from subscription fees and from advertising.

headline.main: Healtheon And WebMD Plan to Buy News Service

docs.abstract: Healtheon Corp and WebMD Inc, companies that are combining in attempt to dominate use of Internet by health care industry, are buying Greenberg News Networks, privately held medical news service, for $250 million in stock; companies plan to use extensive medical information created by Greenberg's Medcast service to enhance WebMD site, which has sections aimed at medical consumers and doctors; they will also create medical news service that will distribute articles to other news organizations, to increase WebMD's exposure (M)
